Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Historic Economic Intergroup Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This project examines how the spread of agriculture and pastoralism impacted the economic and governance practices of hunter-gatherer communities. Previous scholarship has generally described this process in two ways, assuming that hunter-gatherer communities survived through either: 1.) Isolation from farmers and herders across frontier boundaries; or 2.) Symbiosis with neighboring food-producing communities as ritual specialists and producers of wild resources. In the latter scenario, it is assumed that close relationships between these groups often led to the gradual assimilation of hunter-gatherers and the loss of generalized hunting and gathering of diverse resources as a viable way of life as governance and economic systems became more dependent on specialized production. Archaeology is well placed to provide new information about long-term relationships between hunter-gatherers, farmers, and herders in order to address the project’s key questions: What led to the survival of hunting and gathering groups into the present? What role does the use and exchange of natural resources play in the formation of political and economic systems capable of withstanding changing social and environmental conditions? This research is relevant to contemporary challenges, such as the nature of resilient economic systems or concerns about flexible responses to food security. Collaborations with local governmental and educational institutions will promote scientific literacy, increase training opportunities for students and officials, and add tangible value to cultural heritage sites. <br/><br/>This project rests on materials recovered through prior fieldwork. These materials offer critical evidence about human interactions over a period when agriculture and pastoralism entered into the region and became dominant. Analytical methods have included systematic surface and subsurface sampling, selective surveys of rockshelters, and excavations at open-air sites and rockshelters. The research will generate high-resolution, informed reconstructions of the region’s history while also contributing to global, comparative studies of hunter-gatherer diversity and history. This project will include radiocarbon dating and chemical analysis of diagnostic artifact assemblages.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dissertation “Historical Landscapes of the Sandawe Homeland, North-central Tanzania” was completed with support from the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. This archaeological project investigates how hunter-gatherers (also known as foragers) in eastern Africa responded to the spread of agriculture and pastoralism and the emergence of large-scale trade networks over the last three millennia. NSF funding was used for radiocarbon dating of time-sensitive artifacts and chemical analyses of artifacts produced using non-local materials. These analyses were conducted on artifacts recovered during previous fieldwork and were intended to refine our understanding of the distribution of archaeological sites in time and space, as well as to identify connections between the study area and other regions. These analyses permitted a close examination of existing models of forager history by generating data against which these models’ hypotheses could be tested.

Northern Tanzania is one of the most complex regions of Africa in terms of ethnic, linguistic, political, and economic diversity. Additionally, it is home to multiple communities with traditions of hunting and gathering, including the contemporary Sandawe people. Northern Tanzania is critical to long-term histories of Africa, yet there is little material evidence about how the diverse foraging societies of this region organized themselves in relation to major changes in human history, such as plant and animal domestication or the development of large-scale exchange networks. Based on ethnographic and linguistic data, the Sandawe homeland has been portrayed as an isolated refuge that was shielded until recent centuries from the political and economic transformations that reshaped the broader region. By association, its resident population has often been imagined as having been foragers from time immemorial until this situation changed just before or during the advent of colonialism in the late 1800s. Between 2015 and 2018, we conducted intensive archaeological survey and excavations in the Sandawe homeland, locating over 375 sites ranging from the Early or Middle Stone Age to the recent past.

Radiocarbon dating on charcoal, slag (a byproduct of iron production), and ostrich eggshell beads was conducted at the University of Arizona Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) Laboratory. Chemical analyses using Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) and X-ray Fluorescence (XRF) were conducted at the Field Museum of Natural History’s Elemental Analysis Facility in Chicago. These chemical analyses were conducted on glass beads and obsidian, a volcanic glass traded extensively through prehistory.

The results of the radiocarbon dating and chemical analyses contradict historical reconstructions that emphasize the isolation of ancestral Sandawe until recent centuries. As one example, radiocarbon dating indicates that pottery production, metallurgy, and possibly pastoralism and agriculture began by at least 350 AD, which exceeds previous estimates by 1,300 years. Further, patterns of landscape occupation suggest that these technologies were widely adopted by inhabitants of the study area. Similarly, we now know that the homeland’s inhabitants had well-established links to local and global exchange networks, from the Rift Valley zone of eastern Africa to the Indian Ocean World and beyond. Chemical analyses of obsidian used to make stone tools indicate that this material originated in central Kenya, about 325 miles away, and was possibly transported to central Tanzania from 750 BC to 1650 AD. This represents an approximately 30% increase in the distance over which obsidian is documented to have been transported in eastern Africa and is the second farthest known transport of obsidian on the continent, following the trade of obsidian by ancient Egyptian societies. Glass beads from Asia and Europe may have arrived by at least 1650 AD, and cowry shell (which was also used as currency in many parts of Africa), iron, and plastic beads point toward the diversity of sources and long-term importance of these items to past and present inhabitants of the region.

Beyond the specific questions of the dissertation, the NSF-funded analyses generated data relevant to major questions and ongoing debates within anthropology and archaeology. For example, radiocarbon dating revealed a tradition of ostrich eggshell bead production that originated over 45,000 years ago and continued for tens of thousands of years. These findings will contribute to scholarship on the emergence of symbolic behavior in early human communities.

Completed in 2021, this research contributes new data and insights to archaeological research in Africa. Specifically, it provides new perspectives on African hunter-gatherers and reassesses their roles in the history of eastern Africa. The NSF-funded analyses suggest that characterizations of the Sandawe homeland as a hinterland are based not on the actual isolation of its inhabitants but, instead, on a misrecognition of how they have engaged local ecologies and other peoples and places through time. Knowing how regional communities have flexibly adapted to their changing historical circumstances is directly relevant to contemporary challenges in Africa, such as questions of economic resilience, sustainable living, and food security.
